StudyObjective: This study examined whether perceived friendship quality was related to better mental health and lower neural stress response in young people with CA.
Exclude: individuals were eligible to participate if they were aged between 16 and 26 years, able to speak, write, and understand English, had a body mass index (BMI) between 18.5 and 29.9µkg/m , did not currently take medication (e.g. corticosteroids) likely to compromise the interpretation of our data, had no MRI contraindications, and self-reported CA experienced before the age of 16.

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: a well-validate acute psychosocial stress paradigm combining the stress-eliciting effects of high cognitive demands (solving math problems under time pressure) with negative social feedback (on screen and verbally via the experimenter)

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: a game-like, intrinsically motivating task
fMRITasks.DesignDetails: participants completed a stopwatch task (a task that was proven to be intrinsically engaging for adults; Murayama et al.,  ,  ; Sakaki et al.,  ) while being scanned in an MRI scanner
TaskDesign: participants were instructed that they could win or lose points during the stopwatch task depending on their performance, and their overall goal was to earn the total point of zero or larger than zero at the end of the experiments

BehavioralTasks.TaskDescription: the control condition
BehavioralTasks.DesignDetails: participants then passively viewed a stopwatch that automatically started and stopped; they pressed a button after the stopwatch stopped

StudyObjective: to understand why the DMN could be implicated in both costs and benefits to reading

StudyObjective: to investigate which brain regions are activated during food choices during HE compared to LE energy snacks in weight-concerned women
Exclude: having a food allergy, having an eating disorder, having a history of medical or surgical events that might significantly affect the study outcome, such as metabolic or endocrine disease, or any gastro-intestinal disorder

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: participants made 100 choices
fMRITasks.DesignDetails: in every trial, they viewed one of the study stimuli (3000 ms, choice period) and subsequently had to indicate with a button press (1500 ms, button press period) whether they wanted to eat a portion of the snack or not
Conditions: viewing one of the study stimuli
indicating with a button press whether they wanted to eat a portion of the snack or not
TaskMetrics: activation during HE (but not LE) snack choice in brain regions involved in conflict and self-control
TaskDesign: viewing one of the study stimuli
indicating with a button press whether they wanted to eat a portion of the snack or not

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: scoring a soccer goal in a standard two-versus-one situation

StudyObjective: To understand the neural basis of N400 and how it is affected by SZ
Exclude: head injury, neurological disorders, or other medical illnesses compromising the central nervous system

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: in which words were either matched (APPLE←apple) by preceding pictures, or were unmatched by semantically related (in-category; IC, APPLE←lemon) or unrelated (out of category; OC, APPLE←cow) pictures
fMRITasks.DesignDetails: half of the unmatched trials comprised picture-word pairs from a related semantic category (related co-hyponym, e.g., APPLE ←lemon) and the other half comprised picture-word pairs from unrelated semantic categories (unrelated, e.g., APPLE ←cow)

StudyObjective: to show that this assumption also applies to the emotional domain
clarify value processing of consumer goods in the brain

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: indicated their willingness to pay a specific price for that book
fMRITasks.DesignDetails: each good was presented twice: once during the purchasing decision and once during the perceptual decision
Conditions: hedonic and utilitarian goods were presented in a random order
TaskDesign: cued visually so participants knew in which block they were performing

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: indicated the total number of people and lines on the book cover
fMRITasks.DesignDetails: each good was presented twice: once during the purchasing decision and once during the perceptual decision
Conditions: hedonic and utilitarian goods were presented in a random order
TaskMetrics: perceptual levels: the total number of people and lines of the title in the book
TaskDesign: cued visually so participants knew in which block they were performing

BehavioralTasks.TaskDescription: viewed the same books and choose the reasoning for the purchase of each book from among four categories
TaskMetrics: hedonic and utilitarian scores, their knowledge of content presented, and the brightness of the cover

StudyObjective: probe neural responsiveness to anticipated and received rewards in the context of bipolar disorder
Exclude: first-generation antipsychotic medications

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: scanned individuals with remitted bipolar I disorder (  n   = 24) and well-matched controls (  n   = 24; matched for age and gender)
fMRITasks.DesignDetails: each trial (8000   ms total)

StudyObjective: to extend normative neurodevelopmental work into a high-risk population
Exclude: adolescents engaging in high rates of risky behavior

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: where behavioral inhibition was assessed in the presence of appetitive and aversive socioaffective cues
fMRITasks.DesignDetails: during functional magnetic resonance imaging

BehavioralTasks.TaskDescription: assess emotion regulation in the context of socioaffective cues

StudyObjective: examined whether the influence of emotional cues on cognitive control differs between adolescents who show high or low levels of risk-taking behaviour
Exclude: one participant was excluded due to incorrect inhibition on all no-go trials in three of the four runs

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: an emotional go/no-go paradigm
fMRITasks.DesignDetails: within a go/no-go paradigm participants are instructed to press a button as quickly as possible when shown a ‘go’ (i.e., target) stimulus and to inhibit their response by not pressing the button when shown a ‘no-go’ (i.e., non-target) stimulus
TaskDesign: participants were instructed to respond to one emotion and ignore the other

BehavioralTasks.TaskDescription: measures risk-taking under conditions of low and high emotional arousal

StudyObjective: to investigate, for the first time, the functional development of the EBA, pSTS, FBA and amygdala in relation to the perception of emotional human body movements across childhood and adolescence
Exclude: three of the younger children were excluded because of excessive head motion in the scanner

fMRITasks.TaskName: Passive viewing fMRI task using dynamic emotional bodies and non-human objects
Conditions: viewing short videos of angry, happy or neutral body movements

StudyObjective: investigated how the bilateral TPJs associated with ToM were involved in competitive decision making

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: played the game in the MRI scanner with three types of opponents
fMRITasks.DesignDetails: the human opponent (HUM) who played the game outside the scanner and the two artificial agents (FIX and LRN)

BehavioralTasks.TaskDescription: played the game in the MRI scanner with three types of opponents
BehavioralTasks.DesignDetails: the human opponent (HUM) who played the game outside the scanner and the two artificial agents (FIX and LRN)

StudyObjective: to examine the relationship between sleep disruption–induced pain sensitivity and functional connectivity (FC) of cognitive networks contributing to pain modulation
Exclude: two participants were excluded for incomplete fMRI data

to elicit intrinsic network connectivity without the risk of participants falling asleep

StudyObjective: examined brain activation related to parenting and ER in parent-adolescent dyads during concurrent fMRI scanning with a novel task – the Testing Emotional Attunement and Mutuality (TEAM) task.
Exclude: history of major medical or neurological disorders, left-hand dominance [assessed by the Edinburgh Handedness Inventory ( )], current pregnancy, psychotropic medication use (other than stimulant medications) within the past 3 weeks (6 weeks for fluoxetine), stimulant medication use within 36 h prior to the scan, or meeting general MRI exclusion criteria (e.g., ferrous metal implants).

fMRITasks.TaskName: Testing Emotional Attunement and Mutuality (TEAM) task
fMRITasks.TaskDescription: a novel task – the Testing Emotional Attunement and Mutuality (TEAM) task.
fMRITasks.DesignDetails: event-related design and consists of 17 trials during which participants first see a pattern of colored arrows presented sequentially on the screen for 3 s, twice in a row (totaling 6 s).
Conditions: error trials indicating the other dyad member made an error, resulting in a monetary loss for both participants
TaskMetrics: hemodynamic activation of the ventromedial prefrontal cortex
TaskDesign: feedback trials indicating the other dyad member made an error, resulting in a monetary loss for both participants

StudyObjective: to shed new light on the engagement of hippocampal-neocortical regions, and thus the role of memory-based mental simulation processes in pain empathy
Exclude: one participant

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: participants had been randomly assigned to a placebo or control group and completed a pain empathy task, as well as an affective touch task (not discussed here), followed by the structural scan and a resting-state period (not discussed here), all inside the MR scanner
fMRITasks.DesignDetails: separate analyses yielded highly similar results in both subgroups and no significant differences between the groups

StudyObjective: to probe private-public mappings in behaviour and brain activity
Exclude: trials in which the partner’s identity was hidden

StudyObjective: to estimate “brain age” from structural MRI
Exclude: missing age report, major artifacts in a visual inspection of the T1 volume and diagnosis of AD or another form of dementia

TaskMetrics: Pearson correlation coefficient between the network prediction and the chronological age values

StudyObjective: to examine how conformity decisions are evaluated in the developing brain and unfold across social contexts, particularly when adolescents’ own opinions conflict with the opinions of their parents, peers, or both
Exclude: five participants

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: On each trial, participants first viewed a behavior they previously rated (but were not reminded of their original ratings) (2 s). Following a jittered inter-stimulus interval (  M   = 2 s), participants were then shown their parents’ and peers’ ratings on
fMRITasks.DesignDetails: Parents and peers (1) influenced adolescents’ attitudes toward unconstructive and constructive behaviors (i.e., type of behavior) and (2) endorsed attitudes that reflected either more positive or negative influence (i.e., type of influence)

BehavioralTasks.TaskDescription: On each trial, participants first viewed a behavior they previously rated (but were not reminded of their original ratings) (2 s). Following a jittered inter-stimulus interval (  M   = 2 s), participants were then shown their parents’ and peers’ ratings on
BehavioralTasks.DesignDetails: Parents and peers (1) influenced adolescents’ attitudes toward unconstructive and constructive behaviors (i.e., type of behavior) and (2) endorsed attitudes that reflected either more positive or negative influence (i.e., type of influence)

to investigate the temporal changes of the hemodynamic response in white matter as a functional of neuroplasticity

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: during functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI)

fMRITasks.DesignDetails: parallel mixed block/event design

StudyObjective: examined sex differences in the neural responses to wins and losses and how individual reward and punishment sensitivity modulates these regional activities
Exclude: current or past Axis I Disorders including dependence on a psychoactive substance, according to DSM-IV

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: press a button to collect reward ($1, 1¢, or nil)
fMRITasks.DesignDetails: reaction time window titrated across trials so participants achieved a success rate of approximately 67%
Conditions: receipt of dollar or cent reward
TaskMetrics: neural responses to wins and losses

BehavioralTasks.TaskDescription: press a button to collect reward ($1, 1¢, or nil)

StudyObjective: testing the degree with which healthcare providers take into account feedbacks about their pain assessment, and whether they weight in different extent the opinion of the patient from that of other physicians
to test whether shared neural representations between first-hand pain and empathy for pain are pain-specific or extend to empathy for unpleasant affective touch as well
Exclude: neurological or psychiatric disorders

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: In this task, short-lasting (500 μs) and individually calibrated painful or nonpainful electrical stimulation was delivered to participants, or to another person (a confederate of the experimenters).
fMRITasks.DesignDetails: trials were structured as follows: First, an arrow (2000 μs) indicated the   target   (self vs. other) of the upcoming stimulus.
TaskDesign: 15 trials per condition (i.e., self-directed pain/no pain; other-directed pain/no pain)

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: Following the empathy for pain paradigm, we applied a touch paradigm ( ; ) including 15 pleasant, 15 unpleasant and 15 neutral stimuli in pseudo-randomized order.
fMRITasks.DesignDetails: In the first run (self-directed affective touch), the participant was stimulated to measure behavioral responses and brain activation related to the first-hand experience of affective touch.

BehavioralTasks.TaskDescription: Following the empathy for pain paradigm, we applied a touch paradigm ( ; ) including 15 pleasant, 15 unpleasant and 15 neutral stimuli in pseudo-randomized order.
BehavioralTasks.DesignDetails: In the first run (self-directed affective touch), the participant was stimulated to measure behavioral responses and brain activation related to the first-hand experience of affective touch.

StudyObjective: to test whether young and older adults relied on different brain networks during successful spoken word recognition, and whether any age differences were related to the specific task
Exclude: participants with a diagnosed hearing problem

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: no response was required
listeners were 29 young adults (aged 19–30 years) and 32 older adults (aged 65–81 years) without self-reported hearing difficulty

BehavioralTasks.TaskDescription: participants were asked to do the same as in attentive listening, with the addition of repeating the word they just heard aloud

StudyObjective: examined how MT impacts functional brain physiology in the regulation of reactive aggression
Exclude: major uncorrected sensory impairments or cognitive deficits, pregnancy, left-hand dominance, diagnosis of medical or psychiatric illness within the last 3 months, hospitalization within the last 3 months, change in medication regimen within the last 8 weeks, self-reported current drug abuse, presence of MRI safety risks (e.g., ferromagnetic implants, body weight > 300 lbs.), or a history of head trauma or seizures

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: a 16-trial game in which participants could respond to provocation by choosing whether or not to retaliate in the next round

BehavioralTasks.TaskDescription: play an online computerized game with a participant situated in another lab

low noise levels chosen by ostensible opponent

StudyObjective: identify consistent differences in neural activation as a function of whether the target of social cognition was an in-group or out-group member

Conditions: in-group emotion perception > out-group emotion perception
out-group emotion perception > in-group emotion perception

StudyObjective: address the highly debated question of whether neural responses previously linked to affect sharing could result from the perception of salient affective displays
Exclude: videos of six demonstrators (three females)

nine video clips containing both painful and neutral videos

Exclude: subjects who showed a mean displacement over 2 mm

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: inhibit their reflexive eye movement to an abruptly appearing peripheral visual target and to reprogram a saccade in the opposite direction

Exclude: the time period during which the aversive stimuli were delivered

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: combines a classical n’back task with mental arithmetic
fMRITasks.DesignDetails: reproduces the mentally challenging conditions that operators face during degraded contexts
TaskDesign: n’back WM and mental arithmetic processes

TaskDesign: small or large number of valuable coins to friends or unfamiliar peers

StudyObjective: investigate the perception of scene-related, spatial information embedded in two naturalistic stimuli

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: visual spatial perception
fMRITasks.DesignDetails: annotation of cuts and depicted locations
Conditions: contrasted them with events that should correlate with non-spatial perception to a lesser degree, or not at all

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: non-visual spatial perception
fMRITasks.DesignDetails: annotation of speech spoken by the audio-description’s narrator

StudyObjective: examined age effects on consolidation-related neural mechanisms and their susceptibility to interference

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: participants saw a stimulus, showing a colored photograph of a natural or artificial (man-made) object

StudyObjective: testing the effects of liking, familiarity, and self-selection on older adults

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: The fMRI task consisted of 24 trials altogether.
fMRITasks.DesignDetails: In each trial, participants were first presented with a musical stimulus (lasting 20 s), then they were given the task of rating how familiar they found the music to be (familiarity rating lasted 2 s), and how much they liked the music (liking rating also lasted 2 s).
Conditions: other-selected (researcher-selected) music including well-known excerpts spanning multiple musical genres

BehavioralTasks.TaskDescription: Participants' relaxing playlist contained 2.44 (2.22) of their self-selected pieces at the beginning of the intervention, and 2.38 (2.09) at the end of intervention.
Conditions: listen to their choice of selections from one or both of their playlists for one hour daily, over the course of the next 8 weeks
TaskMetrics: memories, images, or associations with the music

StudyObjective: to study this problem
Exclude: current major psychiatric or neurologic illness, as well as MRI contraindications

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: played with a computer, a stranger, and a close friend who accompanied them to the experiment

StudyObjective: examine the underlying neuronal mechanisms of surgically assisted weight loss
Exclude: MRI contraindication

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: measured through the food cue reactivity task ( ) administered approximately 30 min after deflation/sham-deflation to allow for transportation to the research center and administration of a visual analog scale (VAS) on food intake motivation ( )
fMRITasks.DesignDetails: consisted of 44 food images [22 high energy-dense foods (HED), e.g., ice cream, cookies; 22 low energy-dense foods (LED), e.g., salad, fruit] matched on valence, arousal, image complexity, brightness, and hue, and 44 degraded images to serve as a visual baseline
TaskDesign: food images were presented twice each; degraded images were presented once
Each picture was presented for 1,750 ms followed by a fixation cross presented for 250–4,250 ms

BehavioralTasks.TaskName: VAS on motivation for food intake
BehavioralTasks.TaskDescription: question “Would you like to eat something sweet”
TaskMetrics: VAS on motivation for food intake

StudyObjective: to examine whether high loneliness individuals show impaired interpersonal synchronization during social interactions

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: engaged in movement synchronization, using a novel dyadic interaction paradigm
fMRITasks.DesignDetails: using an interactive computerized paradigm, which enables neuroimaging acquisition from participants, as they engage in a joint activity that becomes increasingly synchronized

BehavioralTasks.TaskDescription: to measure real-time synchronization among interacting participants
BehavioralTasks.DesignDetails: computer-based movement synchronization multiagent paradigm

StudyObjective: investigate behavioral and neural associations in self-regulation across the two domains in human participants
Exclude: depression and emotion blindness

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: reappraisal of emotional stimuli
fMRITasks.DesignDetails: block types (reappraise positive, reappraise negative, view positive, view negative, view neutral) were presented in five different orders that were pseudorandomized across participants
TaskDesign: block types (reappraise positive, reappraise negative, view positive, view negative, view neutral) were presented in five different orders that were pseudorandomized across participants

StudyObjective: to examine how neighborhood disadvantage interacts with racial/ethnic background in shaping neural processing of social threats and rewards in US adolescents

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: measure neural responses to anticipating social rewards and threats
fMRITasks.DesignDetails: Participants completed the Social Incentive Delay Task ( ) while undergoing fMRI
TaskDesign: two rounds of the task, totaling 116 trials (48 reward, 48 threat and 20 neutral)
